subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis . Females of
C . zapoteca
are very distinctive mainly due to the thickened and produced clypeus apically and the extreme variation of its apex which varies from straight to strongly bilobed. In the female the apical margin of clypeus is emarginate with two divergent, thick, pointed lobes. Other species in the subgenus have a small triangular excision medially on the apical margin of the clypeus (
C . agilis
), an apicomedial tuberculate process (
C . barbata
and
C . paraguayensis
), the apical margin weakly emarginate (
C . clypearis
), horseshoe-shaped (
C . nasidens
) or simple, nearly truncate (
C . platygnatha
). Another diagnostic character of the females is the fringe composed of short brown setae at the apex of S 5 , a characteristic also found in
C . platygnatha
but this species can be differentiated from
C . zapoteca
by the strongly flattened dorsoventrally mandibles. Other species of the subgenus S 5 has no fringe (
C . agilis
,
C . clypearis
and
C . nasidens
) or a fringe composed of long brownish setae (
C . barbata
and
C . paraguayensis
). Males can be differentiated from the other species by the hypostomal concavity, which is hirsute only anteriorly and by the shape of the mesoscutellum, with a somewhat impunctate dorso-median ridge. In other species the hypostomal concavity is hirsute throughout (
C . agilis
), almost bare but with a single row of white hairs at its dorsal carinate margin (
C . clypearis
and
C . nasidens
) or hirsute anteriorly as in
C . zapoteca
but the mesoscutellum lacks a dorso-median ridge (
C . barbata
and
C . paraguayensis
).

Redescription. Female . ( DZMG ). “Abelhas da Zona, Metalúrgica MG, COPASA/Barre, 5446-14880 ”. “Belo Horizonte MG, BRASIL
06/05/ 1999
, J. C. Moreira”. “
Coelioxys ( Rhinocoelioxys ) clypeata
Smith, 1879
, F.A. Silveira, det. 2000 ”.

Measurements . Body length: 7.50 mm ; forewing length: 5.31 mm ; head width: 2.29 mm . Coloration . Black except as follow: S 6 dark brown to black; antenna dark brown; mandible, legs, sterna, pronotal lamella, lateral surfaces of T 1 –T 4 red to reddish; S 5 dark brown towards apex; tegula yellowish to light brown; wings subhyaline; veins brownish.

Pubescence . Pale, subappressed on: Paraocular area, below the thickened apical margin of clypeus, gena, mandible basally, labrum, complete transverse fascia on anterior margin of mesoscutum, mesepisternum, legs, basal fascia of T 1 and apical fasciae of sterna. Ocular hairs pale, long (about 0.12 mm ). Scattered erect, slender, brownish setae on paraocular area, supraclypeal area, clypeus, sparsely on mandible. Upper paraocular area with long, brown hairs distinct from those of adjacent regions, oriented mesad, apices of some hairs from each side almost meeting medially. Supraclypeal area, clypeus covered with minute, appressed, slender yellowish hairs. Apical margin of clypeus covered with thick, brown hairs. Slender, erect, yellow setae arising from punctures on vertex and mesoscutum. Thick, yellow setae on tarsi. T 2 –T 5 apical fasciae composed of appressed, plumose, white hairs. Erect, sparse brownish setae on lateral margins of S 5 .

Surface sculpture . Ocellar area coarsely punctate; vertex moderately densely punctate, interspaces between punctures longer than puncture diameter, ocellocular area sparsely punctate; mesoscutum, mesepisternum punctate, mesoscutellum coarsely, densely punctate, dorso-median ridge nearly impunctate; axilla coarsely, densely punctate, without shining areas; T 1 moderately densely punctate, interspaces between punctures shining, larger than the puncture diameter; pregradular areas of T 2 –T 5 moderately densely punctate, interspaces shining, smooth; postgradular areas of T 2 –T 5 shining, with sparse punctures forming transverse row with additional small punctures medioposteriorly, T 6 densely punctate, punctures very small, well separated, more densely punctate apically; S 1 punctate; postgradular areas of S 2 –S 4 moderately densely punctate basally, sparsely towards apex, postgradular area of S 5 sparsely punctate basally, more densely punctate towards apex.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 13 .
Coelioxys zapoteca
. Female ( A–E ): A . Lateral view, B . Frontal view of head (for ocular hairs and mandibles), C . Dorsal view of mesoscutum and mesoscutellum, D . Lateral view of T6 and S6, E . Ventral view of S5 and S6. Male ( F–I ): F . Lateral view, G . Lateral view of head and mesosoma, H . Dorsal view of T2 and T3, I . Ventral view of S4 and S5. (Scale bar = 1.5 mm).

subSubSection.paragraph: Structure . Apical margin of clypeus emarginate, forming two divergent, pointed lobes (but see section on variation for the wide range of forms found within this species). Mesoscutellum with dorso-median ridge medially, subtriangular, posterior margin obtusely angulate. Axilla long, acute. T 6 subacute apically, without sulcus laterally. Dorso-median line of T 6 obsolescent except forming discrete ridge apically with shallow, obsolescent depression on each side. Apex of S 5 truncate. S 6 slender, elongate, lateral margins convergent apically, notches obsolete, tip subacute. Hemitergite 7 much longer than wide, area subtended by the marginal ridge narrow; apodemal region greatly produced anteriorly; lateral process reduced; spiracle close to apical margin of lamina spiracularis; lateral lamella wider than lamina spicularis. Dorsal arm of furcula long. Gonostylus subacute apically.

Male
. ( DZMG ). “ Brasil , MG, Belo Horizonte,
27 .ii. 1992
, M.R. Pimenta, UFMG IHY 1316941 ”. Measurements . Body length: 6.77 mm ; forewing length: 4.89 mm ; head width: 2.29 mm . Coloration . As in female.

Pubescence . As in female except as follows: Face densely covered with pale hairs, hypostomal concavity with shorter patch of short, white hairs anteriorly, posterior margin of hypostomal concavity with long, curved white hairs. Apical white fasciae of T 2 –T 5 broadly interrupted medially, gradular grooves of T 2 –T 6 covered with white hairs. Apical half of pregradular area of S 6 densely setose, less setose on outer margins.

Surface sculpture . As in female except as follows: Punctures on mesoscutum, mesepisternum larger, elliptical; postgradular areas of T 2 and T 3 with elliptical, transverse, densely punctate area medially on each side, composed of small punctures basally, larger punctures apicolaterally; T 6 sparsely punctate basally, densely punctate laterally and on dorsomedian excavation, dorsal ridges sparsely punctate; postgradular area of S 5 moderately densely punctate, interspaces among punctures shining.

Structure . As in female except as follows: Hypostomal concavity almost bare, shorter than half length of compound eye. Spine-like processes of T 5 separated from the surface of the tergum apically. Lateral processes of T 6 long, acute, slightly divergent; dorsal processes short, broad, rounded apically, divergent; ventral processes long, acute. Apical margin of T 7 semicircular, rounded apically, not produced. Apical impressed area of S 4 interrupted by a pair of apicomedial extensions from disc, these extensions delimiting a flat U-shaped area, arms of the flattened process subequal to, or shorter than, the distance that separates them. Apical rim of S 4 bare medially, narrowly depressed, weakly emarginate. Apical margin of S 5 simple, gradulus angulate towards base. Gradulus of S 6 indistinct, U-shaped, nearly reaching basal margin, pregradular areas narrow, elongate, weakly sclerotized on inner margins, strongly sclerotized on outer margins, narrowly acute at base, postgradular area transparent medially, broad at base, basal membranous lip rounded. S 7 obsolescent, represented by two small sclerites. S 8 rounded basally. Gonocoxa compressed laterally, equal to penis valve in length, with some long setae apically.

FIGURE 14 .
Coelioxys zapoteca
. Female ( A–O ): Frontal view of head (for clypeus shape in different specimens). (Scale bar = 1.5 mm).

FIGURE 15 . Distribution records for
Coelioxys zapoteca
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Variation . In females the apical margin of clypeus variously modified: Nearly truncate, slightly emarginate, emarginate and forming two rounded lobes, emarginate and forming two divergent, pointed lobes, bilobed and forming two divergent, thickened lobes laterally and strongly bilobed, forming two divergent, thick lobes with a bare area medially.

Comments .
Moure ( 1951 )
redescribed the female of this species (as
C . clypeata
) and a detailed redescription of both sexes was provided by
Mitchell ( 1973 )
. This species is the most widely distributed of the subgenus, ranging from San Luis Potosí State in Mexico to Santa Fé Department, Argentina . The clypeus in females is thickened and produced apically and the apical margin can be straight, nearly truncate, emarginate, forming two rounded lobes or even strongly bilobed, with two pointed thick lobes. This variation led some taxonomists to describe different species based on this character:
C . clypeata
recognized by
Smith ( 1879 )
by its bilobed clypeus, and
C . bilobata
and its subspecies
C . bilobata schenki
, both described by
Friese ( 1921 )
.
Holmberg ( 1918 )
described the species
C . mesopotamica
based on a male and stressed the deeply bilobed clypeus of this specimen. As
Coelioxys
males have no modifications of the clypeus and considering Holmberg’s description, we conclude that this holotype , which seems to no longer exist, was actually a composite specimen, with a female head attached to a male body. A female labeled by Holmberg as
C . mesopotamica
was found by A. Roig-Alsina at MACN . According to him, this specimen was collected by P. Jörgensen on
X- 20-1909
, a few days later than the holotype described by Holmberg (
X- 11-1909
). The female has no head but otherwise agrees with all the characters found in
C . zapoteca
. The species described by Friese as
C . bilobata
also agrees with all the characteristics of
C . zapoteca
and thus is considered herein as a junior synonym, as is its subspecies
C . bilobata schenki
.

Although usually a robust character, the shape of the apical margin of the clypeus in females of this species is remarkably variable (
Fig. 14
). The strongly bilobed form (
Fig. 14
O ) seems to be the least common, but females with an almost truncate apex or a less strongly emarginate apical margin are found throughout the species’ range. Males from Southern Mexico to Central Argentina do not exhibit any geographically delimitated variation that might be suggestive of there being more than one species. This decision is corroborated by the results of DNA barcoding: the wide range of clypeal forms of females of this species and specimens from Mexico , Costa Rica and Paraguay belong to the same sequence cluster with minimal sequence divergence (
Fig. 18
).

In the light of the above, we consider
C . clypeata
,
C . leucochrysea
,
C . angustivalva
,
C . blabera
,
C . doelloi
,
C . mesopotamica
,
C . bullaticeps
,
C . bilobata
and the subspecies
C . bilobata schenki
to be junior synonyms of
C . zapoteca
.

Host Records . According to data from the literature, unidentified species of
Megachile
are attacked by
C . zapoteca
(
Woiski, 2009 ; CA Garófalo, unpublished data
).
